We use the words leader and commander synonymously. We should not forget that there are far more staff
officer assignments than there are command billets. And a good staff officer can and should display
the same leadership as a commander. While it takes a good staff officer to initiate an effective plan,
it requires a leader to ensure that the plan is properly executed. That is why you and I have been
taught that the work of collecting information, studying it, drawing a plan, making a decision,
is 10% of the job and seeing that the plan through is the other 90%. A well-trained officer is one
who could serve effectively either as a staff officer or as a commander. You know this is the
conversation that you and I have. We've had it at the muster a few times because when and I wrote about
an extreme ownership with Seth Stone and writing on his, writing on his humvee window,
relax. Here's what you do when you start getting shot at, bro. One, relax, two, look around,
three, make a call. And then you and I had a conversation about it and you were lining it up with
the Udalupe and the last thing in the Udalupe is act. After you decide you act and they didn't quite
or act when I put that thing on Seth Stone's board on his window. And the reason I didn't have to say
that is because his platoon was like ready to do whatever the hell he said to do, right? They weren't
having a problem with execution. He was just having a problem with this side. You were only solving the
part that he wasn't doing. You didn't need to add a component that was already happening with that guy.
Yeah. And that's what this is. They're getting people to actually do things. That's what he's saying
is 90% of the job. Sitting there and coming up with a plan is okay. I mean, it's, you know, there's
some small challenges to come up with a plan, but not really. I mean, if you have time to plan,
then you have time to assess different angles and look at things and come up and try different
little courses of actions and run through some war games, some possibilities. And then you got a plan,
you're good. But getting people to actually execute that thing, that's what's a challenge. That's
where dreams die. I'm going to tell you that right now. Dreams die in execution. They don't,
the dream comes out, man. The dream flourishes in someone's mind, right? People go, people live out
the entire fantasy, the entire dream. People live out like echo comes out up with an idea for a movie,
right? He lives out the whole fantasy, the Oscar awards, like the whole thing, the limos,
like the red carpet. He's got that whole thing. But guess what? He fails on execution. Like, it's
like, oh, but now I got to work. Like now I got to take and I got to do this thing. So dreams die in
that in that space between decide and act. That's where dreams die between idea and execution. That's
where dreams die. And that's why a leader, a leader's job is to make that execution happen. And here's
the thing. There's another thing. So, Seth Stone, we got interviewed about the battle of Ramadi
and Seth told the interviewer that I had to like beat, I had to beat my head against the wall
for every operation that we were able to do, which was an exaggeration. But the fact that
matter is, and I would tell that story to the young officers, like if you think you're going to do
a mission without like making that mission happen, you're not going to be able to. It's almost,
it's very rare that you're going to be able to that, that an operation, you come up with a plan
and it and like, okay, I said it in motion and now it's just going to happen. No, you have to like
fight every step of the way. And that's the way it is in business. That's the way it is in life.
Yeah, I, I, I'm picturing trying to convince other people that, that you need to be on board with
when you've come up with a plan, knowing that they're going to have to be on board with that plan.
And when, when he says you're going to beat your head against the wall, I think like you said,
your point is just the amount of sheer work that it takes. You don't just like, hey you guys,
and they're like, cool. And it just happens. It's all the other people and all the things they have
to do and where leadership comes in on that, just to convince people, and I hate to say it,
there are times that are people out there that just want to say no. They just want to say no to your
plan. Oh, yeah. And you, especially if there's rank involved, you can't just tell those people,
what did you get a lead way around those things? And there's so much harder than sometimes people
get credit for. And how often I'll see people run into a barrier and then stop and, and give up that.
And so I literally wrote down dreams, that execution. I mean, it's kind of funny when you say it. But
that's the hardest part. Not the, I could sit at my desk and I would do this all the time in
a room. I had these ideas like, hey, we're going to do this. We're going to go here. We're going to
make all these things happen. And then reality is in there. And the hardest part about there,
that is the people you have to get on board to making this stuff happen. Not your people
going ready to go execute, but all the things that get in the way of to the point where you can go
execute that plan.
